cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah lat call at Tor, (for Sinai), El Wedji and Yambo as required.

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The Alexandria Municipality, as an international institution suitable for such a city as this is, may be considered to be the best of the kind that could be invented, for it combines all the essential drawbacks of a great representative institution with none of its advantages. The municipal councillors, who are elected on an extraordinarily limited and artificial franchise, derive a great deal of importance from their self-allotted duties. Most of them remain in Europe from the spring until late in the autumn, and there is no obligation for them to attend to the ordinary routine of their municipal functions. They enjoy an enormous privilege, for they are quite free from public opinion, which is non-existent here, and they rigorously prohibit the Press from being present at their meetings. The reports of their assemblies are carefully edited and doctored before being sent to the newspapers, and only rumours as to the real state of affairs consequently leak out. With all its faults the Ministry of Public Works is considered by business men to be far better to treat with than the Municipality, and we have only to observe the progress which Cairo has made within the last few years in order to form a comparison between the efficiency of the two bodies. It is, however, ridiculous to complain of the Alexandria Municipality, for in the nature of things it cannot be better, as it is unreasonable to expect that a Municipality can be essentially better than the city whose destinies it controls. Alexandria, in fact, does not deserve a better institution, and if it bad more unselfish and public-spirited members of the Municipality it would not know how to appreciate them, but would so misinterpret their motives that they would be forced to retire from public life in despair.

No better proof of the logic of our standpoint on this matter need be adduced than to cite the proceedings at the recent discussions on the subject of introducing fresh sources of taxation. At the penultimate meeting of the Municipal Commission several propositions for fresh taxation were agreed to. The most important of these was the impact on retail dealers of alcoholic liquors, it being impossible to get at the wholesale dealers owing to the commercial treaties. The week before last our Municipal Councillors, having obviously
H. & C. FLICK,
Cigar Importers.

being won over by the interested 'parties, stultified themselves by putting off the application of this tax until the Greek Kalends. There was no genuine discussion of the reasons for the postponement of this most useful tax, and the interests of a great city were cynically flouted on behalf of a small class of retailers who happen to enjoy votes. | There is no need to blame the Councillors. After all they only acted according to their own lights, and having no other ideas than t) be secure of their seats at the elections fifteen months hence they naturally obeyed the orders of the drink-retailers, who otherwise would have voted solid against them. They would thus have lost their seats and been in all probability replaced by more unsatisfactory persons. It is therefore ridiculous to criticise our Municipal Councillors as we notice with regret that our local contemporary La Réforme has in a recent issue. Our excellent confrere, in its leading article, said :

Qu'on s'y prenne, d'ailleurs, comme on voudra, il n'est pas possible que l'on ne finisse pas par s'émouvoir en ville de la situation actuelle. Les questions municipales nous touchent dans nos intérêts immédiats, et lorsque l'on verra qu'il n'y a pas à attendre de nos conseillers des décisions, suivies d'une exécu. tion rapide, il se produira un mouvement tel que l'institution, elle-même, en sera atteinte dans son essence, car l'impuissance pour l'ac. tion sera la condamnation du régime international
Quand donc pourrons-nous écrire après une séance : la Municipalité a décidé ceci ou cela et les travaux vont commencer dans quelques jours !
Il n'est plus permis d'accuser l'administration ; celle-ci attend l'impulsion du corps délibérant et doit être prête à la suivre.
Si on ne fait rien, c'est que les conseillers municipaux ne le veulent pas, voilà ce que l'on sera bientôt en droit de proclamer.

In our humble opinion all such criticism is beside the mark. Neither the Municipality nor its councillors can be more efficient than they are now, as they must ipso facto be on a level with the city, and on the whole they are quite as good as anything that Alexandria deserves.

div.head: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
div.p: There is a very serious discrepancy between the way in which the Mixed Tribunals and the Native Court at Cairo regard cases of cruelty to animals. This discrepancy is so startling that it deserves publicity, for it is a scandal that there should be such a divergence between the points of view of two different judicial systems working in the same city. From January 1 to the 12th inst. the Mixed Courts in the Capital had 23 cases brought before them of Europeans working old, wounded, and emaciated animals ; there were four acquittals and nineteen fines of P.T. 5. But the Native Courts inflict fines of P.T. 100 and P.T. 50 in such cases. Why there should be this differ. ence we do not know, but it is sincerely to be hoped that the Mixed Tribunals will follow the example of the Native Courts, and be in future more severe. Even the latter are by no means as strict as they ought to be, and there is a startling difference between the convictions in Cairo for gross cases of cruelty and those in England. A man at home that works a starved horse covered with whip marks would get a fine of £5 or a month's imprisonment. Here, however, a fine of P.T. 5 or P.T. 10 is all that judges think Europeans ought to pay. As the Courts persist in such a flagrantly lenient policy, it is not worth while for the police to bother themselves to bring the charges only to be made ridiculous by such nonsensical sentences. When an Anglo-Egyptian veterinary surgeon officially states that "the animal is starved, the wounds are old, and it is a gross case of cruelty," it would be enough, we should think, to ensure the offender being fined P.T. 100 at least. The Mixed Courts at Cairo do not appear to think so, and such an attitude is most discouraging to the police, so that the sooner a more draconian view is adopted the better. How can the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which is doing splendid work at Cairo, be encouraged when the law courts are so lenient ! Yet there is plenty of scope for it in Cairo. It is by no means an uncommon spectacle to see private carriage horses with pieces of skin torn off their flanks' by the hamess. Many of the cab horses are overworked ånd underfed in spite of the rise of tariff some months age. The worst cases of cruelty that can be seen in Cain occur where building operations and taking place. There overloading is almost habitual, and many horses have broken knees caused in starting or getting the carts close up to the buildings to unload. Tourists, instea i of doing harm to the natives by the indiscriminate scattering of backsheesh. might economise in that direction and contribute to the Cairo S.P.C.A.

div.head:
DRINK IN EGYPT.
QUESTIONS IN PARLIAMENT
div.p: The question of the imports of drink into Egypt has beeu intere-ding some members of the House rf Cemmons, and the following is the text of the questions that have been recent­ly asked : —

Dr. Rutherford (Middlesex, Brentford) 1 beg to ask the Secretary if State for Foreign Affairs whether he will procure from the Egyp tian Government, for the information of the House, a statement as to amounts and values of alcoholic liquors imported into Egypt during each of the years 1400 to 1906, showing the places of origin and destination and the natioaalities of the consignors and consignee* , also a statement of the number of distilleries and breweries for the manufacture of alooholio liquors, showing in each case the towns and provinces in which they are situated, and the amounts and values of the outputs together with the nationalities if the proprietors for each of the years between 1900 and 1906.
Sir Edward Grey : I will make inquiry and get as much of the information ssked for as is obtainable.

div.head: EGYPTIAN BREWERIES AND DISTILLERIES
div.p: Mr JM Robertson (Northumberland, Tyne side) 1 beg to ask the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether in Egypt it is necessaiy that licences should be obtained for the opening and working of breweries and die tillerie*, and, if so, for what period such are granted; whether arrangements are in force for the inspection and supervision of such Iraweriesand diitillerie*, and for testing the quality and strength of the liquors produced, whether there is any law as to a copy of the same being produced for the information of the House, together with a statement as to the number of prosecutions, convictions, and repea'ed convictions of offending brewer* and distillers under such law, showing their nation alitiea ai d the penalties inflicted in each case during the years between 1900 and 1906.
Sir Edward Grey I will endeavour to obtain the information desired by the bon. Member.

div.head: RETAIL LIQUOR TRADE IN EGYPT
div.p: Mr J. M. Robertson . I beg to ask the Secre­tary of State fur Foreign Affairs whether he will procure for the information of the Hoose a copy of the licensing law relating to the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in Egypt, together with a statement a* to any modifications that may have been made therein, as to the present number of licensed and unlicens­ed retailers, and details of prosecutions and convictions of licensed and unlicensed re. tailers, and of persons charged with drunken nasi in connection with thore establishment*, in each of the year* te'w-ren 1900 and 1906 ; and whether the law, if any, relating to the adulteration of a'ooholic liquors in Egypt applies to, and is enforced against, retailers as well a< manufacturers.
Sir Edward Grey ; I will ask for as much of the information desired by the hon Member as ii obtainable

div.head: CHRISTMAS. CELEBRATION AT HELOL'AN.
div.p: Whatever may have been done in other parts of Egypt for the wvlfare and happiness ot our guests during the 'X-na* holidays Helouan can at least take credit to itself for having provided most seasonable enjoyments for its visitors. Ths Grand Hote', besides providing a firstolaas dinner in all respects, commencing with turtle soup and finishing with good old English plum padding, had also a farther treat in store. One end of the large dining ball was illuminated by a beautiful 'Xmas Tree tastefully decorated and lighted with electric lamps of different colours. At the close of the dinner Dr. Hobson announced that the management had provided a further entertainment in the form of a tombola, or Italian lottery. Each guest bad a card given him containing certain numbers. Thsmaitre d'hfltel "Joseph then called out the numbers from the tombola. As soon as the possessor of a card had a complete row of five numbers as called out he then had the tight to select a prise from a table covered with a collsctioo of beautiful presents all nicely conooalsd in appropriate wrappers. As there were over 100 priiM every guest had the privilege of present­ing a winning card and making his selection accordingly.

The collection of prizes was so numerous that space forbids our describing them all, but we must congratulate Mr. Manuel on receiving a most beautiful ladies' embroidered bolero. Lady Gilbert Parker was the early recipient of a beautiful prize. Rev, Campbell and Mr Fildes vied with one another in their race to be early at the tables, both receiving das rewards. Mrs Seligman and party were very successful in their drawings. The members sf Countess Karolyi's family constantly appeared to be very del ghted with the amusement and were received with cheers whilst going to re caive their prizes. Altogether a most enjoyable evening was passed We bear that a grand ball will take place on the last day of the year, to see the new year in and the old year out.

div.head: CHRISTMAS SERVICES.
div.p: ST MARK'S, ALEXANDRIA

The services on Christmas Day were largely attended, the numbers at the 7 30 a m. service being nearly double that of last year. At the 11am. service every seat wax occupied, including about 60 chairs which were placed in the aisle and at the west end ot the church. The choir sang the "Te Deum" to a setting by Rev E Vine Hall. The anthem was "Behold, I bring," by the same composer. Two offertory sentences were song and the first part of the service closed with the National Anthem. The Communion service was a simple setting by the Rev. F A. Gore Ouseley, though the time was by oo msans easy. The singing of the music was excellent, and did the choir credit. The two soprano solos in the anthem taken by Miss Callender, and the playing of the organ by Mr Heaton, were specially worthy of note.

The church and chapel were tastefully decor ated. Among those who sent offerings of flowers were Mrs. Batobeller, Mrs. Callender, Mire Coates, Mr J. E Cornish, Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Dickson, Mr B W. P. Foster, Mr and Miss Morrison, Mr*. Binger, Mrs W T. Smith. Those responsible for decorating the church were Mesdamrs Eyre, Roberts, and Algernon Ward, Misses Barwell, Dodd, Morrison, and Talbot, and Mr Heaton.
The collections throughout the day were for the fond for the poor and amounted to P.T. 2,133 5 10.

div.head:
CORPORATION OF WESTERN
EGYPT.
div.p: It has been brought to our notice that state­ments are being made to the effect that the recent series of article* which we published on the present state if the development of the concession of the Corporation of Western Egypt were directly or irdir'ctly inspired by the company. Tbi* allegation is quite ui true. The articles were the outcome of a trip to the Great Oasis made by the writer, the editor of thi* newspaper, on hia own initiative, and not a single one of the artiolei were revised by or subtfiitted to anyone interested in the company prior to their publication in the 'Egyptian Gszette." Our object was merely to set before the Egyptian public a straightforward, matter of fact statement of the beginnings of what is really the moat important land development scheme that has ever been attempted in modern Egypt

div.head:
THE TEMPLES OF LUXOR.
A SUGGESTION
div.p: ( PROM UUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT. )

Loxor, Dec. 25. There are no occasions more likely to oppress 08 with a painful sense of our shortcominge and want of knowledge than our first visits to the wonderful and awe striking temples round about Laxor. Vainly do we con our guide books and read long accounts of the insoriptions that tell their bistory, and endeavour to commit to memory long stringe of dimensions that ought to, but don't convey some inkliog of their grandeur. No sooner bave we passed bevesth those heavy pylons and found ooreelves like pigmies at the feet of stalwart statoes and mighty pillars than all recollections of our former stadies fly from our minds; and nothing is left but the wonder that goch things should be, and that we also should be allowed to be in such close proximity to them. If only the elements of Egyptology could be taught us in our youth, perbaps we might in time become reasonably familiar with the history of the great gods and rulers of Egypt, ond might follow the telling of their deeds with some degree of intelligence. Instead of which we stand amszd at the immensity of the subject, our minds bent to the sigoificance of it, and our feat from stumbling over the pitfalls of our ignorance.

I have often wondered why some enterprising person has not instituted a series of lectures to be delivered on the very soones of interest in the neighbourhood. Would some of the well koown professors on the subject condescend to take them each in turn and explain them on their very sites, I take it that a vast number of people would be only too gratified to avail themselves of tbe oppor tonity to garder the fruits of their learning; wbereas now it is impossible to accept or remember a tithe ot the garbled information which the ordinary dragoman is pleased to impart. Lactares at home or even in Cairo are all well enough in their way, but they would gain considerably in value and popularity could they only be delivered on the spot. A series which might be given daring ton days or a fortnight, and which would ombrace the temples of Luxor and Karnak on one side of the river, and that long series of marvellous tombs and coloasi and Theban remsing on the other, would tempt many people to continue in the neighbourhood, and would bring still more notoriety to the researches of the exploration companies.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
"CARMEN."
div.p: 1 came in rather late in the 2nd act, after hearing the singing at Sbepheard's and I wish ed I had s'ayed at Shenheard's. "Carmen" was really just about as bad as it could be. The only relieviag feature* were Ml'e Devilloy and M Fontaine. M. Fontaine, for once, seemed to have freed his voice: it was clear and resonant, and without effort in the lower register. Id fact, all his usual faults were, for onee, absent. Mlle Devilloy was delightful, co sweet and true, and with such a charm in every note, that she was encored, and we all wished Mioae'a were a big part instead of being only secondary M&ry as E*oamillo seemed to me very apathetic , I was told the Toreador song was not by any mean* wonder fol. Mme Chaix Bonheur, of whom 1 had heard so much, was most disappointing, and far too melodramatic; her voice wasn't pleasing at all: it was too coarse and masculine, as was indeed the whole of her interpretation. The rest of the singers and the orcheatra were al! at sixes and leven*. quite tuneless, out of time, often actually singing false. The orchestra was just possible when by itself, but the moment any singing began everything went wrong. I quite agree with " L'Egypte'a " proposal to change them radically and entirely They evidently have no spontaneity or responsivene**, and they play badly, and no amount of bard work will improve them The result is that only the fdw good singers oan do anything, and that by forcing them selves and rest on to the right note, or com promising on the wrong note. The others and 'he chorus have no chance against such discordant apathy

div.p: Gb'r reh Palace Hotel is already in great vogo*. and the number uf visitors at present staying there compares very favourably with that at the same time last year The genera! manager, Mr. Muller, talks cheerfully of bright prospects and a record season, an opinion which ie backed up by a pile ot advance book ing'. Christmas was passed quiet'y at Ghsz reh, but the small danoaa will be inaugurated thia evening, and the preliminary preparation* are already in progress /or the great annual ball.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: Last Saturday's small dance at the Savoy Hotel was, as usual, a great success. The Neapolitan band performed during dinner and for the dancing. The restaurant was very crowded and beautifully decorated with red bokomviglias. Among those giving dinner | parties we noticed : Mr. Gutmann and a party of 10, inoluding Mr. Carpby, Mme. Agbion, Mr. and Mrs. Spitzer, Mr. Heller, and the two

Misses Anderson ; Capt. Bailey and a party of 18, including Mr. and Mrs. Sobneider, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, Mr. and Mrs. Gorbam, and Mr. Carter Wilsor. We also noticed Lord Rosslyn with a large party, and Mokhtar Pashs.

A small dance will take place at the Savoy as u90al on Saturday next, and an extra small dance will be held there on New Year's Day, which also promises to be a great 8000088. Many tables bave already been booked at the restaurant.

END OP WAR IN SIGHT

div.p: The Bondelzwart tribe has surrendered in Damaraland and given up their weapons. The officials here hope that the war is nearly over.
(Reuter)

div.head:
CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE
SERIOUS SITUATION

div.p: The enforcement of the Separation Law is oreating a serious situation in lower Brittany. The olergy are preaching revolt against the law. Commerce is at a standstill and agricul- tural operations are suspended in many districts. (Reuter)

A brilliant Christmas Day was followed by heavy snowstorms in the evening all over the United Kingdom. The storms were especially severe on the south coast, where the blizzard is still raging. Four inches of snow fell here. (R)
A racial conflict took place in Mississippi in consequence of a dispute with the guard of a train. Fifteen persons were killed, mostly negroes. Troops have been ordered to the scene. (Reuter)
The sentence on Admiral Nebogatoff has been commuted to one of 10 years' imprisonment. (Havas)
Mr. Bryce has resigned his seat in the House of Commons.
(Reuter)
The South Africans beat Monmouthshire by 17 points to nil. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE BUDGET.
FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE,
div.p: (Continued)
FOREIGN TRADE.
The estimated figures of the exports and imports of merchandise and specie for the year 1906 are shown below together with the totala for the last six years, as given by the Customs Returns

row.cell: • The figures in this column represent only 90% of the market value of the exports, 10% having been deducted by the Customs before levying export duty.

div.p: The large increase in the exports for 1906 is, of course, dae to the abundant cotton crop and the high prices ruling. The upward move- ment in the imports is hardly less remarkable, raising their value as it does to a figure which is some 10% higher than that of 1905. This notable progress appears by the customs returns to be shared by nearly all classes of the import trade, the most prominent advance being in the category of metal and machinery, which alone accounts for 40% of the total increase.

In my Note last year I said: "The fact that during the past two years the imports of mer- chandise and specie taken together have greatly outbalanced the exports, notwithstanding the constant heavy charges for the service of the foreign debt, constitutes a phenomenon that calls for reflection. A readjustment in the direction of normal equilibriam must come sooner or later, and, if we are paying for our imports with capital provided by the foreign investor, the operation, though by no means unsound at present, cannot be indefinitely continued." These remarks were somewhat severely criticised by a portion of the local Press, which was inclined to accuse me of economic heresy and pessimistic fore- bodings. In the passage quoted above I was far from desiring to formulate any economic theory, heretical or otherwise, but the fact that the total imports of merchandise and specie in 1900 amounted to LE. 18,200,000 as against L.B. 21,600,000 for exports, leaving a balance of LE. 3,400,000 in favour of exports, while in 1906 the figures are, imports LE 31,900,000 and experts LE 28,500,000, showing a balance of over LB. 3,400,000 in favour of imports, is a phenomenon worthy of attention and study. Even if these figures imply that Egypt has been paying for her imports with funds advanced by the foreign capitalist, there is nothing necessarily alarming in the fact, so long as the capital in ques- tion is employed for the purpose of remanera. tive enterprise.

A special feature in the budget of last year was the reduction of the import daty on certain articles of first necessity from 8% to 4% ad valorem. Unfortunately, the condi- tions which have prevailed during the past year are not such as to furnish a fair basis on which to form a definite opinion as to the precise effect of this redaction. In the first place, there were considerable accumulations of stocks to be disposed of before the consumers could expect to benefit by the reduction, and secondly, foreign market prices and freights for most of the articles were higher this year.

Moreover, the state of the local market for cattle and petroleum was abnormal, owing to quarantine restrictions, and to the temporary stoppage of arrivals of petroleum during the disturbances in Russia.

Judging, however, from the data before me. I am inclined to think that, having regard to the recent rapid advance of prosperity, a reduc- tion of 4% on articles of first necessity will not be found, for the moment, to have affected the consumption to any very great extent, whatever the final results may be. If this view proves to be correct, it may, at all events, be claimed for the messure taken last year that, while it benefits the consumers, it also furnishes the Government with a fiscal reserve which could be made use of in case of emergency with the least possible disturbing effect upon trade.
The following is a comparative table of the articles on which the import duty was last year reduced:

table.head: Comparative table of imports on which the duty has been reduced from 8% to 4% ad valorem.

div.p: COTTON.

Although the area devoted to cotton has steadily increased of late years, the total amount of the crop has scarcely varied, and it was feared that over-cropping had seriously impaired the productivity of the soil.

The record of this year does not altogether bear out this theory. The present cotton season has proved very satisfactory. The total crop will probably exceed that of its prede- cessor by from one-half to three-quarters of a million kantars.

The superiority has been very marked in Upper Egypt, where in the season of 1995 the crop was disastrous. In spite of a considerable dimination of area in this region, the total crop of this year will exceed that of last year. In quality also it is superior.

Climatic conditions generally over the whole country ware favourable, and the water supply plentiful. Somewhat cool weather late in September and early in October caused some anxie'y, but a hot spell improved matters a: d the later crop proved satisfactory. The feature of the season has been the high prices ruling. The season opened auspiciously in this respect, and towards the end of the year prices reached an extremely high figure, especially for Joan- novich. This fact, together with the increased yield, has meant a gain to the country of some five or six millions sterling in ex0388 of the profit of last year. In spite of high prices trade demands in England, the Continent and America have been good. Demands in the fine yarn trade have been excellent.
As regards the quality of this year's crop, the middle qualities have proved superior to last year, though there have been complaints that the finer qualities leave something to be desired.

With an extension in the cultivation of Egyptian cottons in other parts of the world, it cannot be too strongly impressed that, if our cottons are to hold their supremacy in the market quality most receive very careful attention. With an increased demand for those high class goods for which Egyptian cotton are extensively employed, there must naturally e be a growing demand for high grade cottons. In this connection the question of seed selec tion is one which requires every consideration and attention.
The out-turn in ginuing in the early part of the sesson was not satisfactory, and, though better results were obtained later in the year, yet the result is bat moderate.

The past season has been fortunate in respect to insect attacks. The cotton-worm did prac tically no harm, while the destructive boll worm appeared much later in the season and in mach diminished numbers.
The cotton crops since the year 1897 have been as follows:-
GOLD DEMAND OF THE EGYPTIAN MARKET.
It may not be out of place here to offer some remarks on recent imports of specie to Egypt which have attracted some attention in the financial world.

Gold coin is invariably imposted in considerable quantity in the autumn in order to move the cotton crop, the amount required depending on the value of the crop (quantity X price), the rapidity with which it is brought to market, and the reserves already existing in the hands of the banks. The first of these is usually the predominating faotor. In the present instance, the exceptionally large volume of the crop and the high prices it commanded, coupled with the fact that the cultivators took the opportunity of selling their cotton earlier than usual, brought it about that the demand tor gold made itself felt with great suddenness at the beginning of October. The reserves in the Banks were quickly exhausted, and a temporary financial stringency ensued, which was ultimately alleviated by the arrival of gold from Europe.

The demand for gold in large quantities for Egypt, constituting as it does a phenomenon of annual occurrence, would probably have passed without comment had it not fallen, concentrated and sudden, upon a marke already short of supplies. The withdrawal of some four millions from the London money market for Egypt during the month of October was doubtless the principal cause of the advance of the Bank of England rate to 6% It may be observed here that no rise in the rate of interest will arrest a drain of gold to move the Egyptian cotton crop, for, owing to the reluctance of the native cultivator to accept anything but actual coin in payment of hi cotton, a permanent check to the supplies would stop the entire commerce of the country and lead to the most serious consequc. In view of the apprehensions which have found expression in some quarters, it is the more necessary to lay emphasis on the fact that the recent demand for gold was a purely trade demand, and was in no way connected with the financing of speculative operations. Although it is incontestable, as I had occasion to point out in my last Note, that such opera- tions have been fostered to a considerable extent of recent years with the help of foreign capital, they should not be confounded with the normal and legitimate commerce of the country. It is, indeed, gratifying to learn, on the authority of the British Chamber of Com merce, that "speculation in stocks and lands was reduced to its lowest limit during the past few months" (British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt Monthly Journal, November, 1906, artiole on "The Financial Stringency in Egypt").
EGYPTIAN COMPANIES.

It my last Budget Note, I drew attention to the fact that the incorporation of an Egyptian Company by Khedivial Decree only implies that the Company in question has conformed to certain roles and regulations; it does not imply that it enjoys the support, or even the approval, of the Khedivial Government.
The system is an antiquated one modelled, I believe, on an old French law long since repealed.

It is the custom of the Khedivial Govern- ment to authorise all companies which conform with the letter of the regulations. Last spring, however, it was brought to the notice of the Ministry of Finance that the creation of "Founders' shares" was being carried to an abusive extent, and, on the advice of the Legal Advisors to Government, it was decided by the Connell of Ministers on June 2 to limit the creation of such shares to cases in which they represent property in an invention, or a Government concession of which the value is problematical.

In foreign countries the regulations laid down are often less stringent than those which obtain in Egypt. The result has been that companies whose incorporation in Egypt wa refused have been successfully floated elsewhere This has notably happened in the case of ope Company which with a capital of L E. 100,000 in 25,000 LB 4 shares proposed to issue 100,000 Founders' shares. It has, I understand, been registered as a British company.
REDUCTION OF TAXATION.

Of late years it seems to have been expected almost as a matter of course that, as December came round, some remission of texation in the succeeding year would ba announced. The limits within which snob remissions are possible has, except as regards the reform of the Customs tariff, now almost been reached. Had the conditions of the past year been normal, the Government would cer- tainly have considered the advisability of taking a further step in tariff reform. Under the unfortunate conditions which marked the early part of the year, and in view of the possible recrudescence of similar difficulties in the future, accompanied by a corresponding increase in the demands on the national parse, it has been deemed advisable to take no measures calculated to diminish the financial resources of the administration.

In deference, however, to the wishes expressed last year by the Legislative Council, a small reform has been adopted by the abolition of the Ayloola dues hitherto levied by the Ministry of Finance. When land is sold by beirs who have not previously accomplished the formality of proving their title by means of a deed in the regular form, it is customary for the Madiriebe to claim payment of the Ayloola daes before transferring the property to the name of the purchaser in the Land tax Registers. In such cases, the dues will not be demanded in fatare, but they will continue to be levied in the Mehkemehs when a title is applied for and a Hodget Ayloola is delivered to prove the same. The loss to the Treasury is estimated at LB 18,0 0.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: EGYPTIAN AND LONDON BOARDS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,-In view of the secular strife that is ever being waged between the local and London boards of Egyptian companies I have a most valuable suggestion to make, which I am sare would be most useful. A large amount of friction might be avoided if company pro- moters in Egypt, when soliciting British capital for their enterprise, were to state that after allotment the services of London boards of directors would be dispensed with.-I am, etc.,

div.head: SULTAN'S PRESTIGE IN EGYPT
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, I notice that the Alexandria cor- respondent of the "Globe," writing from that city on the 1st inst., gives an epitomise! account of the description I sent you of the reception at Damanhoor of Ghazi Mahktar Pasha and conclades as follows:-

In several particulars the sooount quoted is obviously overcharged, but it proves the endaring potency of the Saltan's influenes throughout Egypt, and that in Islam Turkey is never so vietorious as when she fails.

I beg to reaffirm all I said, and to state that the correspondent of the "Globe's" statements as to my report having been exaggerated is absolutely untrue, as the story I told was a plain and unvarnished account.

div.head: THE PORT SAID AFFAIR
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE Sir,-In reference to the correspondence which has appeared on this subject, permit me to say that what may have appeared a heavy punish ment is not as severe as the writer himself would like to give such people. It must be remembered that a number of people who unfortunately call themselves British subjects behave in such a manner that strong messures must be adopted in the attempt to suppress these disgraceful outbreaks of rowdyism among t Britishers abroad. Such men as the one in question, what may be termed the "ball dog style," are evidently under the impression that they can do and aot just as they think fit, and from persons! knowledge I congratulate our worthy Consul General on his efforts to bring sach anraly characters to their proper senses. I trust that last example will prove a warning to others. I am, eto,

div.head: SOLDIERS' INTEMPERANCE
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,-Fêting 'Xmas is natural and indeed proper. But is it necessary for certain soldiers of the Army of Occupation to display the results of too much good cheer quite as publicly? Two nights ago I observed an excellent man gloriously intoxicated asking a puzzled shawish the way to the Ezbekieh within 50 yard of Shepheard's. A group of Egyptians watched derisively till the soldier titubated over one of the Tanzim's obstacle tracks towards the Bristol Hotel On the same evening several other sights of the sort might have been seen. I am glad to admit that there is a great improvement in our Army in the matter of temperance, but something remains to be done, and in a country like this the spectacle of a drunken soldier does not improve our prestige among Moslems.-I am, eto.,

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: THE IMPORTS IN OCTOBER.
(From the Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce).

The steady rise in the monthly clearances recorded daring August and September was quite left in the shade by the returns for October, when the total imports amounted to LB. 2-721,461, being an increase of L. E. 216,911 over the same period in 1905. The total gain for the current year from the 1st January to the end of October was nearly L.B. 2,000,000, the actual figure; being L.E. 19,180,097, against L.E. 17,221,409.
CEREALS.

Although the enormous increases in the cereal classification have somewhat abated during recent monthe-mainly due to exceedingly heavy shipments for the same periods in 1905 -the division showed an expansion of over L.B. 25,000 for October. Flour was L.B. 31,106 up, though this was nullified by a drop of L.B. 32,220 in the maize figures. The deliveries from Burmah, valued at L.B. 54,650, were some LE 16,000 above last year's olearance, whilst the miscellaneous cereals contributed an increase of L.E. 13,668.
CHEMICAL PRODUCTS.
The returns for medical preparations and chemical manures were L.E. 41.715, or an increase of L.B. 14,918. Artificial manures were received from America to the extent of L.E. 27,859.
COLONIAL PRODUCE

COFFEE. Out of the 876,281 kilos of ooffse valued at LB. 33,163 which reached Egypt daring October, America was credited with LB. 80,032 and, farkey L.E. 2,373. The rise over the whole was L. B. 8,665.

SUGAR. Whereas Russia, Roumania, and Austria all made heavy shipments of augar twelve months ago, the two former countries dropped out of the trade in October, whilst Austria only for warded L E. 2,715 against ber previous figures of LE. 19,000. Germany increased her hold on this market with con- signments worth LE 2,864.
METALS.

The total returns in this category at L.E 466,853 were more than double those of September, whilst the increase compared with 1906 was one of LE. 101,968. Great Britain contributed L.B. 194,957, Germany L.B.52,318, France L.E. 13,119, and Belgium over LE 117,000.

IRON & IRONWORK. Girders and other beavy forms of iron work to the extent of 18,194 tons (LE. 107,843) were passed through the Customs during October. The remainder of the clearances ander the classification were valued at LE. 125,032. Compared with last year the expansion on the division was LE 87,069.
MACHINERY-GENERAL.

Shipments to the extent of LE. 126,532 were received, the greater part coming from England. France did L.B. 16,872, Austria L.B. 7,533, and Germany L.B. 4,465. The increase was L.B. 74,791 over October 1905.
LOCOMOTIVES. The drop of L.E. 39,790 in locomotives does not call for any comment) except to note that the whole of this amount wae debited to Great Britain.

BOLLING STOCK The home country did not contribute to the rolling stock deliveries during the month, this fact accounting for the decrease of LE. 34,032 ander the section Belgium completed orders to the extent of L.B. 29.350, whilst Spain was credited with L.B. 1,192.
TEXTILES.

The imports under this heading totalled little over three quarters of a million pounds of which England had L.E. 419,594, Austria L.E. 85,2 5, France LE 67,926, Italy L.E 45,357 and Germany L.E. 37,706. The ing arease over last year's figures was L. B. 74,475 MANCHESTER GOODS. - The clearances amounted to L.E. 361,361 against L.E 283,780 during the previous October. Compared with the first ten months of 1905 the additional imports of Manchester goods this year was LB. 77,581, which figures we imagine will be considerably increased by the 31st December, The clearances by weight for the month were 2,799,178 kilogrammes, and by measure 1,674,219. metres.

WOOLLEN GOODS-In woollen goods, 481,313 metres (LB. 61.185) were received during October, against 491.932 metres (L.B. 63,319) last year England, of course, led the way with -LE. 31,840, followed by Austria (L.E. 12 68). France (L E. 10,095), and Germany (L.E 6,129). As a matter of possible interest we may just mention that during the current year the above countries shipped woollen goods to Egypt to the extent of 89,644 metres, 391,645 metres, 591,013 metres and 240,514 metres respectively.

SACKS. Practically the whole of the sack shipments were made from ludis, Great Britain being only credited with LB. 65 The weight of the goods amounted to 1,338 830 kilos valued at L.B. 31,124, against 1,788,498 (L.B. 40,044) twelve months ago.
WINES AND SPIRITS. The movements in the various sub divisions
of this category were insignificant, with the exception of petroleum, which showed a shrink- age of LE. 54,793.
BEER.-The quantity cleared during October was 13,151 barrels, and 17,283 dozen bottles. These figures compare with 10.828 barrels and 14 470 dozen bottles in 1905.
SPIRITS AND LIQUEURS. The clearances by weight were 73,140 kilograms, in addition to 12,080 dozen bottles. Last year for the same

month the returns ware 101,680 kilos. and 13,684 dezin bottles. PETROLEUM-With the exception of LE 68 from Russia, America was the only country landing petroleum in Egypt during October. The number of cases cleared was 74,987.
TIMBER AND COAL

Each item in this division showed an increase, the total expansion amounting to LE. 74,852. TIMBER-The total imports were valued at L.E. 144,231, or a gain of L.E. 40,421. Sweden shipped L.E. 71,727, Turkey LE 27,766, Austria 20,191, and Roumania L.E. 12,082.
COAL.-171,283 tons valued L E. 127,969 were received, against 150,673 tons (LE. 116.042) last year.
FURNITURE-Castom dues on the substan- tial sam of L.E. 49,518 for furniture, etc., were paid daring October, the returns being L.B. 16,799 to the good.
BUILDING MATERIALS, ETC.-This classifica- tion was again to the fore with an increase of L. E. 22,785. The marble and stone figures- principally from Italy-were 6,352, whilst lime, plaster and
higher by L.E.
cement showed a gain of L. E. 9,660. In this latter division, Belgium supplied L. B. 6,944 and Great Britain L. E. 2,286.
ENGLAND'S SHARE.

Out of the total imports of L.B. 2,721,461 Great Britain was credited with L.B. 886,417, whilst ber share of Egypt's additional trade during the month was L. B. 107,950, giving the satisfactory percentage of 49.7.
Excluding the metal division, the main movements in England's olearances compared with last year were as follows:-
INCREASES
Manchester goods L.E. 86,962, coal L.E. 12,200, flour LB. 8,148, and far- niture L.B. 6,398.

DECREASES. Mathematical and musical instruments L. B. 9,140, and jewellery 1.E.3,684. In metals, the combined machinery olasses showed an expansion of LB 0,756, whilst the railway supplies were L.E. 67,775 lower.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL.
K. 8. C. v. K. O 8. B.

The Borderers made their initial appearance at Ghezireh last Saturday, 22nd inst., against the Sporting Club, and at once stamped them- selves as a team of more than average merit, and signalised their arrival by an easy victory over the home team.

It was rather after the advertised time, when, having lost the toss, and defending the tennis courts goal, Wyatt kicked off for the club. There was little to choose during the first few minutes and each end was visited in turn, but once the visitors had found their fset and the pace of the ground they began to show glimpses of their form, and frequent bouts of pretty passing brought them within hail of goal. The bome back division were kept continually busy, and although not quite as certain as usual offered a strong resistance. It was evident that the determined attack set up by the regime t must result in a score and at the end of a quarter of an hour a concerted movement on the left wing brought the ball into the centre and Woods again transferring to Forbes, the latter bustled through the remaining opposition and easily beat the fruitless effort of the goalkeeper at rushing out, The club left wing then broke away and on sveral occasions threatened danger; but Douglas was equal to all emergencies. After a short interval of midfield play, Jones raced away and centred well from which Woods nearly scored, but the ball was only partially cleared and Priestly, getting possession well ap, scored with a very clever shot. Starting again the home forwards made rather a better show and eventually got through. Paten and Deacon initiated the movement on the right and Frye, receiving the centre, proceeded to fall over it, but with Douglass out of his goal, he recovered himself suffi iently to roll the ball just over the line. With the score st 2.1 ends were changed, and Woods kicked off again. The Borderers were now playing good game and kept the home defence hard at work and before ten minutes had elapsed a further disaster befell the club. Stout seemed to entirely mi-judge a soft shot from the left wing and the goal- keeper, being unable to get across in time, the ball rolled geatly into the corner of the net. Roused to a sense of their responsibi lities, the home team made determined efforts to reduce the deficit. Once Wyatt failed to take advantage of a go'den opportunity and shortly after saw a hot shot well savel by Douglass. The latter on several occasions had shots to deal with, but many of them lacked ating, and Gh-zireh were unable to penetrate the sterling defence pitted against them With Woods scoring a fourth goal after a olever manoeuvre, in which he gave the goalkeeper no chance, the K. O. S. B.'s won their first match by 41.

The score hardly reflects the merit of the respective teams, but weak shootings and the mistake of the third goal were responsible for giving the appearance of a run-away victory in what was a good game to watch and not so one-sided as the score would in- dieste. For the club, the forwards were com- bining rather better, but were still very weak in' shooting. Their goalkeeper did many good hings and Wes'ey fed his forwards with his nsual commendable accuracy. The Borderers will prove themselves a great addition to Cairo fotball. They are fast, clever, and play with any amount of dasb, and from a first impression appear to possess in Donglass and Priestley a goal keeper and centre half of distinot ability.

K. O. 8. B's. Sergt. Douglass, goal; Sergt. Pearce and Pte. Hope, backs; Pte. Prieve, Sergt. Priestley, and Lieut. Crake, half-backs; Pe. Jones, Loe. Corp. Jones, Capt. Woods, Lieut. Forbes, and Pte. Ingler, forwards.
HELOUAN SPORTING CLUB.

We would remind our readers that the first winter meeting of the H 8.C. will take place to-morrow (Friday) at 2 p.m. at Helonan. It will be seen from our issue of yesterday that the number of entries for the different races is exceedingly good, and that the best of sport may be expected.

For the convenience of visitors the Towfik Palace Hotel issue combined rail, lunch, and race coupons as follows: P.T. 55 for gentlemen and P.T. 40 for ladies, to inelade (a) 1st class rail to Helouan; (b) lunch at the Tew fik Palace Hotel; (c) entrance to members' enclo sure and paddock; (d) afternoon tea; (e) return rail to Cairo.

A special traia will leave the Towfik Palace platform immediately after the races, and the Egyptian Cavalry Band will play a selection of music at the Tewfik Palace Hotel during lunch and in the members' enclosure during the races.
Combined race coupons are on sale at Bab- el-Louk station and at Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
A. S. C.
The committee of the A.8.C. have decided to hold a Horse Show at the Sporting Club grounds on Saturday, the 13th April, 1907.

Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907
